qas.question: Which diplomat leaked information about the secret agreements?
Which ally of Germany was most surprised by the signing of the agreement?
How long had the tripartite discussions been taking place?
Which diplomat never leaked information about the secret agreements?
Which diplomat leaked information about the public agreements?
Which ally of Germany was least surprised by the signing of the agreement?
Which ally of Germany was most surprised by the scrapping of the agreement?
How long hadn't the tripartite discussions been taking place?

context: On 24 August, Pravda and Izvestia carried news of the non-secret portions of the Pact, complete with the now infamous front-page picture of Molotov signing the treaty, with a smiling Stalin looking on. The news was met with utter shock and surprise by government leaders and media worldwide, most of whom were aware only of the British–French–Soviet negotiations that had <b7_0>taken <a2_0>place for months<b7_0/><a2_0/>. The Molotov–Ribbentrop Pact was received with shock by Nazi Germany's allies, notably <a1_0><b5_0><b6_0>Japan<b6_0/><b5_0/><a1_0/>, by the Comintern and foreign communist parties, and by Jewish communities all around the world. So, that day, German diplomat <a0_0><b3_0><b4_0>Hans von Herwarth<b4_0/><b3_0/><a0_0/>, whose grandmother was Jewish, informed Guido Relli, an Italian diplomat, and American chargé d'affaires Charles Bohlen on the secret protocol regarding vital interests in the countries' allotted "spheres of influence", without revealing the annexation rights for "territorial and political rearrangement".
